Authors:
, Massimo Pessino, Ember T Chabot, Rosanna Giordano, R
Edward DeWalt
Title:
Refugia and postglacial expansion of Acroneuria frisoni
(Plecoptera: Perlidae) in North America.
Keywords:
Acroneuria frisoni, Plecoptera, glacial refugia, COI,
population structure, Bayesian clustering
Abstract:
The Illinoian and Wisconsinan glacial episodes influenced
the distribution and genetic structure of most North American animals
and plants. We inferred the demographic history of Acroneuria frisoni
Stark & Brown, a widespread eastern North American stonefly, using
the mitochondrial gene cytochrome oxidase I (COI). Results show that
this population is highly structured and survived glaciations in at
least three refugia in the southern portion of the present day
distribution range. The population that recolonized the upper Midwest
originated from the refugium located in the Tennessee River valley. A
second refugium was located in the southern portion of the Ozark
Mountains of Missouri and Arkansas and contributed marginally to the
recolonization of formerly glaciated areas. The third refugium was
likely located in the valleys of the Appalachian Mountains, and the
haplotypes that diverged therein are now distributed exclusively in
southern Pennsylvania and in the Tennessee River valley. Results
indicate that populations west of the Mississippi River have been
isolated from those in the east for at least 180K years, suggesting that
glacial cycles interrupted gene flow between these two regions and that
the present day Mississippi River and associated lowlands are an
effective barrier to dispersal.
